spanishExample: ¿Quiénes son los que van a poner *the flowers* ahí?
englishTranslation: Who are the ones that are going to put the flowers there?
vocabIncluded: "los que" to mean "which" after a preposition
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Aunque nos ponemos esta ropa, no *we like them.*
englishTranslation: Even though we put on these clothes, we don’t like them.
vocabIncluded: ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Él pone sus cosas en su *box.*
englishTranslation: He’s putting his things in his box.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella hizo eso, lo cual es *the right thing to do.*
englishTranslation: She did that, which is the right thing to do.
vocabIncluded: lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)

spanishExample: Ella pone sus cosas en su bag.
englishTranslation: She is putting her things in her bag.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Hay personas quienes ponen cosas donde no tienen que ir.
englishTranslation: There are people who put things where they don’t have to go.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: He puesto *effort *and *intelligence* en esto.
englishTranslation: I have put effort and intelligence in this.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Los *books,* los cuales no tengo, son los que siempre pones ahí.
englishTranslation: The books(m), which I don’t have, are the ones you always put there.
vocabIncluded: "los que" to mean "which" after a preposition
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Me pongo algo en las manos por la sangre, mientras tú haces eso.
englishTranslation: I’m putting something on my hands because of the blood, while you do that.
vocabIncluded: pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Me pongo esta ropa porque la he querido con todo mi ser.
englishTranslation: I put on these clothes because I have wanted them with all my being.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Mi querido hijo, tienes que poner tus cosas en su lugar.
englishTranslation: My dear son, you have to put your things in their place.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Ponemos las cosas donde siempre las hemos puesto.
englishTranslation: We are putting the things where we have always put them.
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Se podrían poner tristes si *they saw* sus cuerpos.
englishTranslation: They could get sad if they saw their bodies.
vocabIncluded: podrían: "would be able", "they would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person plural)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"

spanishExample: Se pone esa ropa, pues *it’s very hot.*
englishTranslation: She puts on those clothes, for it’s very hot.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Se ponen tristes porque su mente no es lo que era.
englishTranslation: They are getting sad because their mind is not what it used to be.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si ponen las manos en *the fire,* se van a *burn.*
englishTranslation: If they put their hands in the fire, they’re going to burn themselves.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Si te pones eso en la boca, *you’re going to get sick.*
englishTranslation: If you put that in your mouth, you’re going to get sick.
vocabIncluded: pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Si pongo *the cat* en *the cage,* él se pone triste.
englishTranslation: If I put the cat(m) in the cage, he gets sad.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si te pones *that shirt, it will match* con tus ojos.
englishTranslation: If you put on that shirt, it will match with your eyes.
vocabIncluded: pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Tenemos que poner la *milk* en la *fridge;* si no la ponemos, *it’ll go bad.*
englishTranslation: We have to put the milk(f) in the fridge(f); if we don’t put it, it’ll go bad.
vocabIncluded: ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que darle una mano con su cara.
englishTranslation: You have to give him a hand with his face.
vocabIncluded: darle una mano a: "give a hand to" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Todas las noches pongo la cabeza en la *pillow,* la cual es muy *soft.*
englishTranslation: Every night I put my head on the pillow(f), which is very soft.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)
